voice.text: Let's begin by looking at a basic 3D model without any material applied.
What you see here is the raw geometry of the object, rendered flat.
This means that the renderer is only displaying the shape and silhouette, with no lighting or material details affecting the appearance.
All we see is the model’s geometry, which consists of vertices, edges, and faces that form the surface.
This is the foundation of any 3D rendering, as everything else is built upon this basic mesh structure.
Now, we apply vertex color to the model.
Vertex coloring is one of the simplest methods for adding color information to a 3D object.
In this approach, colors are assigned to the individual vertices of the geometry.
The color at any point on the surface is interpolated based on the colors of the surrounding vertices.
This can give us basic color and shading, but it lacks any realistic interaction with light, as it doesn't take into account how light behaves on different materials.
Now, we move on to the albedo map.
The albedo map is a texture that defines the base color of the surface, independent of any lighting or shading.
It provides the color information for the model, determining how the object will appear under neutral lighting conditions.
The albedo map doesn’t account for shadows or highlights—it’s just the raw color values of the surface material, like the paint on an object before any lighting is applied.
Next, we apply a normal map to the model.
A normal map is a texture that stores information about the direction of each polygon of an object, but without actually altering the geometry.
By using this map, we can simulate small surface details like bumps, grooves, or texture that affect how light interacts with the model.
These details make the surface look much more complex than it actually is, while keeping the geometry simple.
This enhances the lighting realism, giving the illusion of depth and texture.
Now, we move on to the metallic map.
The metallic map defines which parts of the model are metallic and which are non-metallic, or dielectric.
In PBR, metallic surfaces interact with light differently than non-metallic ones.
Metals reflect more light and tend to absorb specific wavelengths, resulting in a colored reflection, while non-metals scatter light diffusely.
The metallic map helps simulate realistic materials like metal, plastic, or wood by specifying which areas behave like metals.
Finally, we apply a roughness map.
The roughness map controls how rough or smooth the surface of the model appears.
A smooth surface, like polished glass, reflects light sharply, creating clear, sharp reflections.
A rough surface, like worn wood or brushed metal, scatters light in many directions, resulting in more diffuse and blurred reflections.
This map is crucial for achieving realistic surface details because it determines how light behaves at the micro-surface level, adding another layer of realism to the rendering.
